COMMISSION OF INQUIRY TO INQUIRE INTO MISMANAGEMENT
OF UNION FUNDS BY PRO-COMMUNIST LEADERS OF THREE
UNIONS
(Statement by the Minister for Labour)


2.32 p.m.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Mr Speaker, Sir, honourable Members will recollect that seven trade unions had their registration cancelled by the Registrar of Trade Unions on 30th October, 1963. The ground for cancellation was that these unions were being used for purposes inconsistent with their objects and rules and had taken part in Communist united front activity prejudicial to the good order and security of the

Column: 306

State. Before cancellation, these seven unions were given two months' notice on 28th August, 1963, to show cause why their registration should not be cancelled. Shortly after serving notice, official information was received by the Registrar of Trade Unions that leaders of three of the seven unions, namely, the Singapore General Employees' Union, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union and the Singapore Bus Workers' Union, in furtherance of their plan to stir up political unrest and to further the Communist united front campaign against merger and Malaysia, had met on the 1st and 3rd of September and decided to withdraw large sums of money from the bank accounts of the unions they controlled to implement their illegal plan.

    Honourable Members will recall that on the 3rd of September, His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara proclaimed the dissolution of the previous Assembly and everybody was aware that general elections would take place soon. In order to protect the funds of the unions, which rightly belong to the workers, from being misused, the Registrar immediately advised the banks to withhold withdrawal of any funds from the accounts of these unions. Despite this action by the Registrar, two unions, namely, the Singapore General Employees' Union and the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union, however, managed to withdraw from the Bank of China $30,000 from their accounts between the period of 5th and 12th of October, 1963. In one instance, the Singapore General Employees' Union withdrew a sum of $13,500 on 12th October, 1963. When this information came to the knowledge of the Registrar, he sent an urgent memorandum requesting the acting President, the Secretary-General and the Treasurer of the union to see him on 14th October to explain why the withdrawals were made.

    On 14th of October, the three union officials accompanied by their legal adviser, Mr T. T. Rajah, called at the Registrar's Office. They admitted they had withdrawn three sums of $4,500

Column: 307

from the union's bank account with the Bank of China on 12th October, 1963. They explained that the money was handed over to Mr T. T. Rajah to pay Messrs. S. T. Bani, Fong Swee Suan and Sandra Woodhull, the so-called champions of the workers, as a form of ex-gratia reward for services rendered to the unions in the past few years. According to them, the payments were authorised by the union's Executive Committee at a meeting held on 10th October. An official note was then sent on 16th October by the Registrar to the three union officials and to Mr T. T. Rajah warning them not to make the payments as they would be acting contrary to the objects and rules of the union and that such payments are illegal under the law. In his reply to the Registrar, on 17th October, Mr T. T. Rajah stated that as Messrs. Fong Swee Suan, S. T. Bani and S. Woodhull had never asked for a cent from the union and as they were not consulted on the payment of an ex-gratia allowance, he had advised the union to set aside the sum held by him for disbursement for other purposes. In the same reply, however, Mr T. T. Rajah did mention that Messrs. Fong Swee Suan, S. T. Bani and S. Woodhull were given an allowance of $200 per month for pocket expenses. They said they fought for the workers and in the end we found that they were given $200 a month plus $4,500 bonus for making the life of the workers miserable and unhappy and for making more than 1,000 workers unemployed. Say what you like about Devan Nair - workers' thief or aristocrat of the workers but - he has not taken a single cent from any union.

    On the 4th of November, the Registrar again wrote to Mr Rajah directing him to pay the sum of $13,500 into the union's bank account. In his reply on the 5th of November, Mr T. T. Rajah informed the Registrar that he had handed the full sum of $13,500 to the union between the period of 18th and 22nd of October. The Registrar then wrote on the 8th of November directing the three union officials to put back the sum of $13,500 into the union's bank account. The three officials informed the

Column: 308

Registrar on the 13th of November, through Mr T. T. Rajah, that they had acted on his advice and had distributed the $13,500 to those members of the union who were unemployed. To satisfy himself that the money was properly and legally utilised, the Registrar wrote to the three union officials again on the 27th of November asking them to call at his office on 29th of November so that he could ascertain exactly how the money was used. The three union officials failed to turn up on the appointed day. The Registrar again wrote to them on 30th of November fixing a further meeting on 3rd December to give them another opportunity to explain their action. The three union officials again failed to turn up and the Registrar had, therefore, no alternative but to report the matter to the Police on the 4th of December, 1963. The police immediately commenced their investigations and discovered that the General Secretary of the S.G.E.U. had absconded. Why? Is it because he has got something to hide?

    Honourable Members will see from what I have recounted that here is a clear example of how unions under the control of a group of unscrupulous, anti-national, pro-Communist elements can sabotage genuine attempts by the Government to protect trade union funds in the interests of the workers. From the various complaints received from members of this union, Government has ample evidence which indicates that unions controlled by pro-Communist elements had utilised their funds to support the Communist united front campaign against merger and Malaysia.

    In view of the concern over the misuse of union funds and the disappearance of the union official connected therewith, the workers and the public in general would naturally like to know the actual state of the financial affairs in these unions. The Government therefore consider it essential to set up a Commission of Inquiry to inquire into the mismanagement of union funds by the pro-Communist leaders of these three unions. It is proposed to appoint Mr Tann Wee Kian of the Legal Service to be the Commissioner with the following terms of reference:

Column: 309



    To inquire into and examine the financial transactions of the deregistered Singapore General Employees' Union, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union and the Singapore Bus Workers' Union from 1st of April, 1962, to date and to report thereon with particular reference to:

    (a) Every payment which appears to be unauthorised by the rules of the trade union or contrary to the provision of the Trade Unions Ordinance, Chapter 154;

    (b) The amount of any deficiency or loss which appears to have been incurred by the negligence or misconduct of any person; and

    (c) The amount of any sum which ought to have been, but is not brought to account by any person.

    To further safeguard the interests of the workers from being exploited by the anti-national pro-Communist elements in the trade unions, and in view of the urgency of the matter, the Government proposes to introduce a Bill to amend the existing trade union legislation. This amending Bill will be introduced and taken through all stages on a Certificate of Urgency on the 18th of December, 1963. The reason for bringing in the Bill on a Certificate of Urgency is obvious. The Assembly will be adjourning shortly and unless the Bill is brought in and passed on this basis, there will be no effective legislation to prevent trade union funds from being dissipated illegally and dishonestly. However, to give Members an opportunity to study and comment on the Bill, I propose, with your permission, Mr Speaker, Sir, to circulate it to Members today. I will deal with the provisions of the proposed Bill when it comes up for consideration by the House.

Column: 310

relevant to the subject matter of the Ministerial statement.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [28th November, 1963], "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1964.".-[The Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

2.50 p.m.

    Mr Kow Kee Seng (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to give my views on the Budget statement of the Minister for Finance. We note that this year's Budget statement, like those of previous years, is yet another piece of P.A.P. propaganda. Because of Malaysia and Indonesian confrontation, there appears to be a more realistic note this time. At least the P.A.P. admits that confrontation sets back Singapore's progress by two years and that trade severance will have important and far-reaching effects on Singapore's economy. Nevertheless, the P.A.P. makes claims on Singapore being in a strong financial position and predicts that the future, notwithstanding confrontation, holds great promise and opportunity for the people and that achievements in the next four years should exceed those of the last four years. I think the Finance Minister must be saying this with his tongue in his cheek. He knows the serious crisis facing Singapore. Yet he tries to minimise the far- reaching effects of confrontation - I quote the Finance Minister's own words - by injecting an unjustifiable note of over-confidence in the Budget statement. What are the P.A.P.'s reasons for this apparent confidence? Because, says the Minister, the gross domestic product for national income has increased by 26 per cent and the per capita national income has increased by 15 per cent from 1959 to 1962. He further claims that "most of the growth occurred in the years 1961 and 1962 since the implementation of the State's Development

Column: 311

Plan". Let us ask: how has this increase in national income helped to raise the standard of living of the poor? And how has this helped to solve the pressing unemployment problem in the State of Singapore? The P.A.P. boasts of its achievements in housing and in industrialisation, and many people are given the impression by one-sided P.A.P. propaganda that there is a phenomenal economic growth and development in the country. What are the facts? Going by the figures given by the Minister, we can immediately see that there is gross under-expenditure in land, agricultural development, transport and communications, and social development. Indeed much of the surplus funds accumulated over the last few years have been due to gross under-expenditure, inefficiency, and incompetence of the P.A.P. Government. And however much the P.A.P. may like to crow over its so-called achievements, it will not be able to hide the fact that certain essential services in Singapore have been grossly neglected. I will come to them by and by.

    This is the first Budget under neo-colonialist Malaysia, and today all in Singapore can see the great inequalities and injustices that have been done to Singapore under the P.A.P.'s merger terms. Originally a lump sum of $78 million was to be given to the Federation for Federal services in Singapore. Mr Lee Kuan Yew, the Prime Minister, told the people that Singapore must have control over finance. Now control is firmly in the hands of the Central Government and, in addition, we pay 40 per cent of our national revenue to the Federation. This 40 per cent works out to $117 million according to the 1964 Budget. We have to pay for Federal development projects in Singapore, and the sum amounts to $9.5 million. We also have to pay for the running of the departments that are controlled by the Central Government, viz., the departments of Customs and Inland Revenue, Broadcasting, etc. The amount involved is not easily worked out, but it is probably in the region of $15 million. If we add $117 million to $9.5 million and $15 million, the total comes to $141.5 million. If we

Column: 312

further add to this total, the $30 million that we give, the so-called loan to the Federation for the so-called development of the Borneo territories, then we find that we are giving to the Federation $171.5 million next year. This is the price Singapore has to pay as a result of the P.A.P.'s merger and Malaysia. Money which is today vitally needed for the relief of the sufferings and hardships that have been brought to the people of Singapore by Malaysia, is all given away.

    What causes the Indonesian confrontation? However the Minister may care to interpret why Indonesian confrontation has come about, he will not be able to deny the fact that without Malaysia there would not have been Indonesian confrontation. It is clear, therefore, that it is Malaysia that has caused this confrontation. The Finance Minister has given an account of the far-reaching effects of confrontation on Singapore. According to him, we have already lost the earnings of our import and export trade with Indonesia which, in 1962, amounted to a total of $209 million and which works out to about 8.7 per cent of our national income for that year. Some 8,200 workers are also directly affected. But the Minister is under-assessing the gravity of the situation. The situation is much more serious than that. Malaya's trade with Indonesia amounted to $1,325 million in 1962. Of this Singapore's share was $1,100 million, viz., more than 80 per cent. This $1,100 million also works out to about 16 to 20 per cent of the total trade of Singapore. Mr Speaker, the mere withdrawal from circulation of a few million dollars following the pay-cuts imposed on the civil servants by the P.A.P in 1959 had a great depressing effect on the economy of Singapore. Now the loss of $209 million earnings - and this is an under-assessment of the loss - will most certainly affect very severely the economy of Singapore. We can say that practically every person in Singapore will be affected directly or indirectly. For instance, the textile business is 60 to 70 per cent down, the general provisions business

Column: 313

is 30 to 50 per cent down, and even banks that have nothing to do with Indonesian trade complain of a 30 to 40 per cent drop in business. The import and export business is at a standstill and trade in general is fast slowing down. Those most directly affected as a result of Malaysia and confrontation are, of course, industries connected with shipping, rubber, coconut oil, sago, coffee, rattan, pepper and timber. Not only is it a loss of business and trade for Singapore, but what is more important is that there is a greater loss of jobs and livelihood for thousands and thousands of workers in Singapore. The Minister mentioned the figure of 10,800. Any man in the street will be able to tell the Minister that the number is easily many times that. Moreover, there is no estimate of the actual number of those affected who are in partial or irregular employment and who are on contract labour. Waterfront workers, boat transport, taxis, hawkers and small businessmen, all are similarly affected. Ships lie idle in the harbour and even now our fishermen cannot go out to sea with safety. Mr Speaker, in addition, certain essential foodstuffs like sugar, coffee, fish have gone up in price. This already means a small rise in the cost of living, which in turn means extra burden and extra hardships for workers who are already finding it difficult to make both ends meet. Confrontation, therefore, is having a terrible effect on Singapore. Even Singapore's trade with other areas like Hong Kong and Bangkok is indirectly affected.

    We are glad indeed that the Government has made provision for economic defence to help the tens of thousands who have been hard hit by Malaysia and confrontation. The Government has suggested that a worker who is laid off as a result of the closure of his factory is to receive six months' income at two-thirds his normal earnings. This is a commendable move. But we must warn the Government that the amount provided for economic defence is completely inadequate. Only $1 million per

Column: 314

month will not be able to help many people. Moreover, there are many loopholes in the scheme which work to the disadvantage of the workers. Certain employers have already shown that they merely intend to give lip service support to the scheme. For instance, certain categories of workers, like water transport workers and the so-called temporary workers, are not included in the scheme. And certain employers and contractors do not give true reports to the Government. They reduce the workers' normal earnings to the lowest possible average for computation of relief. We would say that a period of six months for the grant of relief is too short. What happens after six months? Or what happens when the employers say that they are not in a position to help further? Moreover, the proposal that all reliefs paid during the six months by the employers will be taken into account in respect of obligations under the law when the final payment is made to workers for closure of business after six months is grossly unfair to the workers, it amounts to no relief being given at all during the six-month period from the Government and the employers. We would urge the Government to study the memoranda submitted by workers and their unions carefully. Their hardships are real. Whether Government gives a subsidy or reduction in rent, light and water charges for workers affected as a result of Malaysia and confrontation must be given serious consideration. We further urge the Government in matters concerning the workers' welfare to consult all workers' unions irrespective of whether or not they support the P.A.P. and not only the National Trade Union Congress. It is the duty and responsibility of the Government to help all workers. The direction of employment can be of help if there is much alternative employment to go to. But the multiplier economic effect is such that all other spheres of employment will be bound to be affected. Confrontation affects mainly the local business. It is correct, therefore, that local businessmen be given all assistance by

Column: 315

the Government. The giving of active encouragement and assistance to the local businessmen is what, in fact, the Government should have done long ago. The industrialisation programme of the P.A.P. has benefited only the foreign capitalists. We understand that about 70 per cent of the capital so far invested in the pioneer industries has come from foreign capital. Instead of wooing British, Japanese, Australian and American capital, the P.A.P. should instead make strenuous efforts to help local capital. But the prospect of industrialisation is not bright. With Indonesian confrontation, a huge market of 100 million is lost to Singapore. Without the large Indonesian market, no big industry can succeed in Singapore. Already the new flour mill, so I hear, is only working at one-quarter capacity because of confrontation. How is industrialisation to succeed under such circumstances? Moreover, Indonesia is opening free ports and free zones in Sumatra to take away the entrepot trade of Singapore. She is now also trading direct with Western countries. The P.A.P.'s threat to close our market to countries that deal direct with Indonesia instead of through Singapore will only mean the deprivation of more workers of their livelihood. It is like cutting one's nose to spite one's face. [Laughter] Mr Speaker, Sir, now we are talking about the hardships and the difficulties experienced by the people of Singapore. Yet the Ministers there are laughing.[Interruption]

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Kow Kee Seng(In Mandarin): So all the proposals put forward by the Government are only palliatives. Some can do more harm than good. The only way to solve the present economic crisis is to get to the root of the problem, namely, to negotiate immediately with the Indonesian Government to resolve all existing differences. Calling Indonesia "hungerland", "blunderland" and "plunderland"; shouting jingoism and the expansion of the armed forces and rousing the people with so- called patriotic rallies and further increasing the tension in the area by registration and mobilisation -

Column: 316

all this will not resolve the basic problem facing the people of Malaya and Singapore and Penang in particular today. The only way is friendly negotiation with the Indonesian Government, and that is why we moved the amendment to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech two days ago.

    1963 being the year in which feverish preparations were made by the P.A.P. for a snap general election, it is not surprising that there is a steep rise in Government expenditure for the year. But in spite of the steep rise in expenditure of $60 million in 1963 as against 1962 largely on Police and television, all for the use of repression and P.A.P. propaganda, there is still a surplus of $47 million plus $9 million to the Federation, amounting to $56 million. If we take away the $44 million of revenue collected in excess of estimates, there is still an under-expenditure of $12 million for the year 1963. If there had not been special expenditure on the building of stand-pipes, electric lights and roads to deceive the people that the P.A.P. was doing some good work during the Prime Minister's so-called constituency visits, which were in fact electioneering by the P.A.P. and using State funds for party purposes, there would have been greater under-expenditure in 1963. Year after year under-expenditure by the P.A.P. has contributed to an accumulation of sizable surpluses. We should now put this surplus to good use in Singapore. The Minister has budgeted for a surplus for 1964. Of course, the Budget was based on the normal year of 1963. However, 1963 is not a normal year. The loss of trade in the last three and a half months of the year may well offset the major part of the profits and earning already made in the first eight and a half months of the year. Therefore, will the estimated revenue of 1964 come up to expectations? I am sure the Finance Minister knows that the estimated revenue in 1963 will fall short of expectations. In view of the need for extra expenditure as a result of Malaysia and confrontation, it is very unlikely that there will be any surplus again in 1964, unless Government underspends on development again. I have already

Column: 317

spoken of the large chunk of our revenue which will be given away to the Federation in 1964 as a result of the Malaysia agreement. The sum given away amounts to nearly $171.5 million. The extent of the financial sell-out of the P.A.P. can now be seen by all. We can see also how much the 40 per cent national revenue means to Singapore. According to the 1964 Federal estimates for Singapore, the amount to be spent on Federal services in Singapore is estimated to be $78 million, but the 40 per cent national revenue which we give to the Federation amounts to $117 million. The difference between percentage payment and lump sum payment amounting to $117 million minus $78 million equals to $39 million - the extra which the Prime Minister has given away to the Federation! And for what - the expansion of the armed forces for the suppression of the people! This is what the perfidious P.A.P. has done with the money earned by the sweat and toil of our people. This means cutting a big slice of funds for expenditure in Singapore, especially funds for the use of development projects and social services.

    The P.A.P. repeatedly boasts of its Four-Year Development Plan. We might as well find out what rates of performance the P.A.P. has really put up. In the matter of housing, the Government claims that it has broken the back of the housing shortage. I do not wish to repeat what has already been said on the subject in the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech. The so-called 119 per cent performance of the P.A.P. on housing is not 119 per cent on low-cost housing that is badly needed by the people of Singapore. If the rentals on housing units that are built are rentals which the people cannot afford, then they are of no use to the people. Take, for instance, the rehousing of fire victims. It is true that the unfortunate fire victims have been very promptly provided with housing flats. There are many such flats lying vacant because they are unsuitable and unwanted by many people though such people really need flats. Now these re-housed fire victims are wondering how they are to get the money to pay the high rentals charged. This is one of the many

Column: 318

headaches of the re-housed fire victims. How does the Minister intend to remedy this state of affairs? The only solution is in building really low-cost houses and not expensive flats. We ask the Government to help the poor immediately by reducing the high rentals now charged by the Housing Board and to build only low-cost housing in future.

    The Four-Year Plan on health states:

    `The need for maintaining a high standard of health services is not purely based on a humane and civilized recognition of the values of human life nor is it purely a desire to alleviate human sufferings. It is also based on economic considerations.'

This is what the P.A.P. said. Where are the public dispensaries, the new hospitals, the new specialised departments and extensions to the hospitals? Why is the Medical Department permanently under-staffed? And why has there been this neglect in the public health of Singapore? The P.A.P. will not be able to deny that development in this field has fallen far behind schedule, to say nothing of keeping pace with the population growth. There is nothing for the P.A.P. to crow over in this sphere. The cholera epidemic is the direct result of P.A.P. incompetence and inefficiency. Page 77, section 7.81, 7.82 and 7.83 of the Four-Year Development Plan envisaged the construction of the Seletar dam and two service reservoirs together with the tapping of water from the Johore River and the Scudai River. Very regrettably much of this field is still in the planning stage. Meanwhile the people of Singapore have to suffer the inconvenience of ten hours of water rationing every day, which started from April this year. We doubt if the Government performance rate in this department even comes up to 54.4 per cent as claimed by the Minister. We ask the Government to start crash programmes to get water from the Scudai and Johore Rivers as quickly as possible. The people of Singapore have put up with water rationing long enough and their health is already dangerously affected. It is high time that the P.A.P. put in more work and play less politics. It is ridiculous that the people of Singapore

Column: 319

should still be short of water supply when we are in the midst of torrential rains and floods. Yet this is another instance of poverty in the midst of plenty.

    This brings me to the Development Plan on flood alleviation. This is the time of monsoon rains in Singapore and floods have already caused serious disruption to road communications especially along the main arterial roads in Singapore. After all the years of P.A.P. rule, what has been done in flood alleviation? According to the Minister, the Government has so far put up only 18.8 per cent performance. Therefore, the various schemes to alleviate floods in Bukit Timah, Queenstown, Alexandra, Orchard Road, Geylang and Toa Payoh seem to have been forgotten to all intents and purposes. Is this not another instance of P.A.P. neglect and incompetence? The swamp reclamation scheme is, of course, far behind schedule. Only nine per cent performance can be recorded. But what about rural development? According to Table III given by the Minister, there is a record of 97.5 per cent performance. However, that refers only to a sum of $1.64 million. The actual amount that should have been spent on rural development for the three years 1961 to 1963 according to Table 7.3 in page 66 of the Four-Year Development Plan should be $20 million. The P.A.P. has therefore put up only a rate of seven per cent performance in rural development. We urge the P.A.P. not to neglect the poor people in the rural areas. Promises were made to help raise the standard of living of the rural people, but they have not been kept. We hope more effort will be made in this direction in the future, not just a few rural tracks and standpipes, but complete electrification and extensions of pipe water supply to all the rural areas. In addition, genuine efforts must be made to help rural workers and farmers to fight poverty and exploitation.

    In the matter of education, the Government is again far behind its schedule especially in vocational and technical education. I do not intend to say much on Nanyang University now, but it is clear to all that the Government

Column: 320

is playing too much politics on the question of aid to Nanyang University. Singapore has the money. Therefore, let aid be immediately given to Nanyang University so that it may freely develop in accordance with the wishes of the people, The Government has, in fact, made promises to implement free secondary education in 1964. The Minister says that this has now to be postponed. Is it really because of the confrontation? There have been annual surpluses over the last few years and we have now $400 million in the kitty. What is holding the P.A.P. back? Was it merely an electioneering stunt to be forgotten after the elections have been won?
